DOC.HEAD: FAA Knew About Moscow Embassy Warning Before Flight 103
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration was advised eight days before the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 that the U.S. Embassy in Moscow was warning employees of a terrorist threat against Pan Am flights on the same route, a presidential panel disclosed Monday. FAA officials acknowledged that they had received a telex from the embassy on Dec. 13, 1988, but said they did nothing about it even though they said it is against government policy to warn employees but not the general public of such threats. The issue of a dual standard in warnings of potential terrorism is one of several being taken up by the seven-member Presidental Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism, which held its second hearing into the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland, of Flight 103, in which 270 people died. The panel also received the results of a congressional report that said stepped-up security measures since the disaster may be ineffective at high-risk foreign airports due to a lack of training standards. The report by the General Accounting Office faults the FAA for not establishing minimum training requirements for people who screen baggage and conduct other security operations at foreign airports. Kenneth Mead, GAO director for transportation issues, told the commission that the congressional watchdog agency has found several ``fundamental deficiencies'' in FAA security programs. Earlier reports, he noted, had found problems with passenger screening, airport security controls and security inspections. Mead said the FAA has concurred with most of the agency's findings and made some changes but does not keep close enough tabs on security on a daily basis. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., a commission member, said the congressional studies indicate that ``the FAA and the present system have flunked when it comes to providing basic security systems that anyone can have confidence in.'' D'Amato said problems with the FAA suggest there may be a conflict between its role of promoting aviation and that of ensuring passenger safety. Producing a copy of the telex from the Moscow embassy to the FAA, D'Amato said it proves the FAA was aware that U.S. officials were warning State Department employees, but not the general public, about the threat. ``Since a number of people from this post will be flying out of Frankfurt in the next two weeks, post plans to issue an internal administrative notice warning employees of the threat,'' said the telex to the FAA. ``No recommendation will be made as to course of action to be followed by travelers.'' Relatives of Flight 103 victims say they believe several government employees changed reservations to get off the flight after the warning, while the general public was not informed of the threat, which specified a Pan Am flight within two weeks after Dec. 5 en route from Frankfurt to New York. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt and was en route to New York from London when it blew up. Officials later said the specific threat that had prompted the warning was not credible, and they believe it was only a coincidence that it came just two weeks before the bombing.
